name: Hindustani Classical Vocal Classes - Weekly Classes
description:
Meet Simran, a Hindustani Classical Vocalist and Teacher whose life has been harmoniously entwined with music since childhood. Disciple of Smt. Divya Shenoy, Simran's voice masterfully blends traditional rigor with emotional depth.
For her, music is more than art – it's a sacred, boundless journey of devotion.
With a rich multidisciplinary background in dance, painting, poetry, and theater, her teaching approach is innately creative.
Join her at Atta Galatta every Tuesday, where music transcends melody, becoming a haven to listen, to express and to belong!
Classes will be on every Tuesday – 5 PM for children and 7 PM for adults. The monthly charges will be INR 2000 for one person. Trial classes available at INR 500 per class.

name: Creative Passage - Art Therapy Workshop
description:
Creative Passage: Moving Through Emotional Darkness with Bridging Art Activity
A transformative workshop 
Whether you're facing personal or professional stress, anxiety, difficulty letting go, or uncertainty about the future — you're not alone. Creative Passage offers a safe, reflective space to explore your emotional landscape and move through it with intention, using the powerful, intuitive medium of expressive art.
What is Creative Passage?
This workshop is grounded in the Bridging Art Activity — a guided creative process that supports emotional release, personal insight, and transformation. Through simple artistic expression, you'll gently explore what’s holding you back, and begin to build a path forward — from emotional darkness towards clarity and light.
Who is this for? This experience is open to anyone aged 18 and above who may be:

Feeling overwhelmed or anxious
Struggling with life transitions or decisions
Holding onto past pain or uncertainty
Having difficulty moving on or letting go

No art experience is needed. This is about the process, not the product.
What you can expect:

A guided expressive arts session using colour, shape, and symbolism
Mindful reflection to deepen insight and reconnect with your inner strength
A supportive, non-judgmental space for emotional exploration

Benefits: Participants often leave with:

A greater sense of emotional relief and clarity
Feeling more grounded, present, and empowered
A deeper understanding of what’s holding you back — and what’s possible ahead

___________________________________________________________________________
Facilitator: Deepika Gupta
Counselling Psychologist, Certified NLP Practitioner, Certified Life Coach
Dance Movement and Art Therapy Practitioner, Certified Grief Counsellor
Bharatanatyam Performer and Teacher

name: In The Name of Love - A Gathering of Resistance & Freeedom
description:
This Independence Week, we gather to speak of love — love as defiance, as protest, as political memory.
In a time when love is regulated, criminalised, and turned into evidence through laws, surveillance, and moral policing, we come together to ask:
What does it mean to love freely?
What does it mean to resist in the name of love?
Organised by The Philosophy Project, this is an open space to think through love and freedom beyond the vocabulary of the nation-state.
Panel Discussion: Love, Law & Resistance
Arvind Narrain and Vinay Kumar joins Naina Bhargava (Founder, The Philosophy Project) in a powerful conversation on how the law has shaped, policed, and also enabled forms of love and freedom.
Arvind is the author of India’s Undeclared Emergency and co-editor of Law Like Love. He was part of the legal team that challenged Section 377.
Vinay is the founder of #ReclaimConstitution and a public intellectual whose work spans innovation, heritage, and constitutional activism.
 
Reading Circle: bell hooks on Love & Freedom
A quiet reading and reflection session exploring love as a political and transformative force.
Moderated by: Naina Bhargava and Lakshmi Nambiar (COO, Outlawed India)
Reading material will be shared with all registered participants beforehand.
Zine Making + Letters to the Nation
Join one or all of our collective making tables:
– Zine Making Station
– Letter Writing Table (write to a past lover, your younger self, or the country)
– Wall of Love — where you can share anything you think of as love: notes, pictures, quotes.
Please bring your own materials (magazines, pens, paper, photos). We will have a limited supply available.
If you can’t be there in person, you’re welcome to email us your letter and we will include it anonymously in our archive.
Please Note:
We are a small, independent collective with no institutional funding. This event is free and open to all. However, seating is limited and entry will be on a first-come, first-served basis.

name: Letters to Dadu: A Storytime for Hearts Big and Small - Storytelling
description:
Join author Aprajita Singh for a warm and engaging storytelling session based on her picture book Summers with Dadu. Set in the world of mangoes, memories, and mischief, this session invites children (and grown-ups!) to relive the magic of holidays spent with grandparents and heartwarming connections across generations.
Come be part of a fun-filled morning of stories, art and writing for the grandparents near and far!

name: We Fed the Whale A Greenhouse - Book Discussion
description:
The AG Lit Sisters invite you to an intimate evening with award-winning journalist and debut author Sonali Prasad, as we dive into her lyrical and poignant novel Glass Bottom, a story of two pairs of mothers and daughters who reside by the sea, navigating the silent intensity of love, loss, legacy, and everything in between.
Set against the shifting tides of the coastline, Glass Bottom offers a tender meditation on relationships, memory, and healing. In this special session, Sonali will read a short excerpt from the novel, followed by a heartfelt Q&A and book discussion with readers.
📚 Hosted by AG Lit Sisters
🎤 In collaboration with Pan Macmillan India
Whether you're drawn to stories that stir your soul or conversations that linger long after they end, this is a session you won’t want to miss.
SONALI PRASAD was born and raised in New Delhi, India. Her journalism has appeared in publications such as the Guardian, Washington Post, Hakai Magazine, Quartz and Esquire Singapore. She has been awarded a Pulitzer Traveling Fellowship, Global TED Fellowship, MIT Knight Science Journalism
Fellowship, Logan Science Journalism Fellowship and a Jan Michalski Writing Residency, among other grants and honours.
Glass Bottom is her first book.
performer:
Dr. Chhavi Gandhi Juneja, 
Sonali Prasad,

name: Journaling Workshop - Slow Journaling Workshop
description:
Best friending journaling – once again!
A chill 2-hour journaling workshop for self-expression, fun, + reflection
Come hang out for a relaxed afternoon where we’ll mix writing, art, and conversation. This isn’t about being “good” at journaling—it’s about showing up, having fun, and getting to know yourself a little better.
Expect:
🎨 Colours, of multiple kinds!
📝 Easy journaling prompts—some deep, some totally weird
💬 Time to share, reflect, and chat with others
Perfect if:
– You’re feeling stuck or rebuilding
– You haven’t picked up a colouring tool in years
– You want a space to express, reflect, and just be
🧺 Bring: your journal (Important), any colours, and a curious mind
Come as you are. No journaling or art experience needed.

name: Queer Quiet Hours - Meetup
description:
The next dates for Queer Quiet Hours are here!  
Queer Quiet Hours is back — a cozy space to rest, make art, and just be. No pressure to talk, no need to perform. Just soft community vibes and gentle company. Bring your own project or come as you are. We'll have plenty of art stuff for you to use.
✨ For LGBTQIA+ folks only. We haven't opened it up to allies yet.

🆓 Free to join. Limited spots.

📸 No photos taken without clear consent.

Spots are limited - Sign up!
